10) The most significant big-picture impact in my opinion, however, is this: **BASE gives us a glimpse of how centralized crypto service providers can become decentralized. In other words, how CeFi can move to DeFi.** This is key. https://t.co/PTrr5pg9tl

9) Bigger picture, Coinbase has been instrumental in onboarding millions into crypto markets. It has a relatively trusted brand, and could therefore also become a gateway to the on-chain economy for more mainstream users. /15

Yet rather than disappointing, this is actually hopeful: it highlights the level of scrutiny the launch will be under, as well as the value of getting a sizeable and critical community to test and test and test. /14 https://t.co/qf7aYFINpF

8) The testnet is live now, and the mainnet is expected to follow within a few months. Initial users yesterday found several glitches, and no doubt there are many yet to be found. /13 https://t.co/GgdNnv3q88
7) Base will start out relatively centralized, with a centralized sequencer and a handful of validators, but the intention is to move toward a totally decentralized network some time in 2024. /12

However, BNB has been criticized for its centralization: it has only 26 validators, although last week it announced plans to increase that to 100. Even so, Coinbase is used to a greater degree of public scrutiny. /11  https://t.co/hzIxSFPouu

6) The initiative is similar to Binance‚Äôs BNB Chain, currently the largest smart contract blockchain in terms of users and transaction volume ‚Äì launched in 2020, it grew so large so fast because of the size of Binance‚Äôs community. /10

5) There are no plans to issue a token. Whether a token is necessary to incentivize adoption has been the subject of much controversy, and the jury is still out. Base will give the market a chance to observe the build-out of value based on utility rather than reward. /9

4) Why would external developers work on Base? Coinbase has 110m verified users, acc. to the Q4 earnings report. In other words, a huge community with plenty of upside ‚Äì only a tiny subset of Coinbase users have ever transacted on-chain. /8

3) The chain will offer open-source tools for external developers to create applications for the Coinbase community. These would in theory put a broader range of use cases in front of Coinbase users than if applications were limited to those created by Coinbase teams. /7

It is also a chance for Coinbase to influence how decentralized applications evolve, by contributing code as well as users. Coinbase will become the second official core developer team in the Optimism ecosystem. üßë‚Äçüíª /6

Plus, creating a new chain ecosystem that forms part of the larger Ethereum ecosystem ‚Äì Base was built using open-source tools from the Optimism stack ‚Äì is a way to more deeply embed Coinbase in the blockchain community. /5

For instance, imagine extending the existing Coinbase wallet to Base, wrapping tokens from other ecosystems and having some of these unlock NFT functionality while creating new identity systems and supporting the emergence of new communities. /4

2) Coinbase doesn‚Äôt *need* a blockchain ‚Äì it already is one of the largest crypto platforms in the world. But its own chain sets the base for a new direction of development, perhaps giving birth to new types of transactions, app connections, etc.  /3

1) This makes Coinbase the first listed company to launch a blockchain. Equity analysts will be scrambling to understand zk-rollups, bridges and more, which should deepen Wall Street interest in and familiarity with the on-chain world. Who knows where that could lead. üïµÔ∏è  /2

While another layer-2 blockchain may sound like more technical noise wrapped in PR hype, it‚Äôs actually a very big deal, and although I am definitely not a developer or even a frequent DeFi user, I think this is exciting on many fronts. üßµ/1

Finally, BTC‚Äôs narrative is multi-faceted, this also lends its floor strong support. For some, it‚Äôs a store of value; for others, an early-stage liquid tech investment; for many, pure speculation, partially based on narratives driven by the first two. Complicated and fascinating.

And whatever bad economic news lies ahead won‚Äôt affect BTC‚Äôs ‚Äúfundamental‚Äù valuation, because ‚Äì again ‚Äì it has no cash flows. What it has is actual, potential and growing utility, the valuation of which will move more on narrative than data. /6

That easy-exit experience positions it to be a strong beneficiary of an increase in risk-asset positions ‚Äì almost a ‚Äúsafer‚Äù bet than illiquid venture equity, for instance. And its recent resilience in the face of bad news is another strong support signal. /5

BTC has no cash flows to discount, so unlike stocks, higher rates don‚Äôt really hurt it much ‚Äì it‚Äôs more about liquidity. Because BTC doesn‚Äôt HAVE to be in portfolios, and because it‚Äôs an easy high-return asset to dump, it suffers when investors reduce exposure. /4 https://t.co/hMCj1xVldh

There are other risk assets out there also sensitive to a liquidity recovery, but none that have already suffered a >70% drawdown AND that have a strong support floor from long-term accumulators who see BTC as a store of value. /3

How can liquidity be improving if rates are still going up? Because 1) stock and bond volatility is coming down ‚Äì this releases collateral, 2) oil price coming down ‚Äì gives people more money to spend on other things, 3) USD trending down, 4) TGA account moving into the economy. https://t.co/VqNlCA8qsf

Really interesting, yields AND BTC going up‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs about liquidity. BTC is one of the most sensitive liquidity plays right now ‚Äì its whopping drawdown last year, its lack of cash flows to discount, its strong floor given its various use cases‚Ä¶ Unpacking this some more: üßµ https://t.co/3QYkBOhsBw

I imagine we‚Äôll hear more from experts later re. other possible arguments the SEC will rely on. The timing is interesting, given the stablecoin regulation expected this year. If they go after other stablecoin issuers as well, this will be a seminal fight for the industry.

The Howey test stipulates there needs to be an expectation of profit for an asset to be a security. That‚Äôs an important leg, but not a deal-breaker. Courts have shown some leeway in the definition of ‚Äúprofit‚Äù, and SEC has suggested this is not a blocker.
https://t.co/FSMtfjavEC

Centralized stablecoins are usually backed by cash, treasuries and sometimes CP ‚Äì since they get their price from securities, they could be classified as a security derivative. Or, since they can be redeemed on demand, they could be seen as a ‚Äúdemand note‚Äù, technically a security

A lot of the reactions I‚Äôm seeing to the SEC/Paxos news are along the lines of ‚Äúbut there‚Äôs no expected profit, so no way are stablecoins a security!!‚Äù. Unfortunately, they could be (*does not mean they be!*). Here are a couple of arguments they might use:
https://t.co/72WgJaZlJU

@glassnode If, however, you consider BTC to be a payment mechanism, then it needs to move. Your valuation method will probably be based on total transaction fees and value accrued to the network. There is no consensus as to what bitcoin *is*, which complicates its valuation.

@glassnode This highlights a bitcoin peculiarity: if you consider bitcoin to be a store of value, then parking it in an address is considered ‚Äúuse‚Äù, and your valuation method will probably be supply/demand based.  /4

@glassnode Can these long-term investors be considered ‚Äúusers‚Äù? Their sitting on BTC may benefit the price by taking some supply out of short-term circulation, but does it boost network revenue? Or does it boost network value through a higher price? /3

Ah, except with bitcoin, of course, it‚Äôs not quite so simple. Excluding BTC that has not moved in >10 years (can probably be considered lost), almost 35% has not moved in over two years. @Investingcom @tradingview In sum, the debt ceiling showdown is likely to be bad, especially for federal workers and for markets already worried about a slowdown in spending contributing to a recession. But, for risk assets moved by signs of liquidity easing, it's actually not bad? Which is weird.

@Investingcom @tradingview 4) It‚Äôs possible that any agreement will include some concessions on government spending. Any reduction there could end up helping to bring inflation down further, which would be especially useful given that it‚Äôs always the ‚Äúlast mile‚Äù that‚Äôs the hardest. /12

@Investingcom @tradingview 3) An increase in the debt ceiling is likely to, well, increase the amount of outstanding debt. At higher rates. Which means that the Fed will have to ‚¨ÜÔ∏èincome somehow, to avoid running up against the limit again in a few months. Yes, ‚¨ÜÔ∏è income in an economic slowdown. /11
@Investingcom since US treasuries were still the world‚Äôs ‚Äúsafe haven‚Äù asset, even when the US is a driver of market risk. Go figure. /10 (chart above via @tradingview)

@Investingcom 2) In theory, this yield drop could be offset by a higher risk premium, given the greater possibility of a US debt default or downgrade. Only in theory, however ‚Äì after the S&P downgrade in 2011, the US 10-year yield actually continued to decline, /9 https://t.co/0wRbRIqFFq

@Investingcom 1) One of the obvious measures the Treasury would resort to is the suspension of US government debt issuance. This decreases supply; assuming demand remains constant, the price should increase and yields drop, complicating the Fed‚Äôs monetary tightening strategy. /8

@Investingcom Is another downgrade on the table? It‚Äôs certainly a possibility, this year more than others given the febrile nature of US politics after the mid-terms. Here is where it gets especially interesting for markets, especially for ‚Äúrisk assets‚Äù. /7

The market seems to agree: US 5-year credit default swaps have spiked back to levels last seen in 2012, the tail end of a debt ceiling crisis that led to an S&P downgrade in US (it currently has the same rating as Austria, New Zealand and Finland). /6 (@Investingcom) https://t.co/i9sFmoT8lB

But this year feels especially prickly given the contentious positioning that has already started, and the problematic nomination of House Speaker McCarthy which resulted in the ascension of several Republican hardliners to various Committees. /5
https://t.co/PrfQHxxpB2
This is not a new phenomenon ‚Äì there seems to be a debt ceiling-related showdown every year. /4 https://t.co/gnKv1g9eNN

But these can work only for a few months before they, too, are exhausted. At some stage, Congress will need to raise the limit ‚Äì if it doesn‚Äôt, it will end up having to default on some of its treasuries, which would be catastrophically bad for global markets. /3

It doesn‚Äôt necessarily imply that the government will shut down tomorrow ‚Äì there are some accounting manoeuvres that can be taken to keep paying holders of treasuries, such as running down the Treasury‚Äôs cash balances and delaying payments to certain government pension funds. /2

However, this time could be different. This bear market, given its different protagonists, could defy previously established patterns and either take longer to resolve, and/or rally harder when it does. /14

It also reminds us that we cannot necessarily take the 2018 bear market as a pattern to follow for the current one. Several on-chain signals are pointing to a floor, with some indicating the consolidation period is almost over. /13

‚Ä¶mean transfer size could hint at a sentiment shift which could trigger the next bull run. Meanwhile, the realization that smaller investors are continuing to participate in a relatively steady fashion is encouraging - it highlights a resilient and distributed investor base. /12

The moral of this story? It‚Äôs this: the entrance of larger market participants brought strong momentum in the 2021 run-up, but also made the fall even more brutal. Their exit is unlikely to be permanent, however, and an eventual upturn in the relative volume trend of‚Ä¶ /11

Now, let‚Äôs go back to 2018. Back then, we see a totally different story. Back then, smaller transactions (~ retail) were driving the narrative ‚Äì the ‚Äúinstitutions‚Äù had not yet arrived. /10 https://t.co/yOAQBi2emI

‚Ä¶ the *weight* of small transfers ‚¨ÜÔ∏èwhile that of large transfers ‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è. When put on same axis, the small transfer trend (~ median transfer) appears flat, which still supports its growing weight in the face of the sharp drop in large transfers (~ mean transfer). /9 https://t.co/B1d22nSbdx
So, while the *overall* volume of transfers is declining‚Ä¶  /8 https://t.co/bU1i47UbyG
‚Ä¶ and the relative increase in small transfers over the same period. /7 https://t.co/KCZKKNy6KY

To further put this into context, we can look at the relative volume trends. This involves taking the 7d moving average and dividing by the 365d moving average, to highlight momentum shifts. This further shows the trend decline in large transfers so far this year‚Ä¶ /6 https://t.co/2EZPPKlT4Z

After this year‚Äôs May/June drama, the mean transfer size, which had been ‚¨ÜÔ∏èalong with greater institutional involvement, started ‚¨áÔ∏è while the median transfer size held relatively constant. In other words, large transfers were disappearing relative to smaller ones. /5 https://t.co/VsD2OZSafq

@glassnode Putting the two on different axes, we see that the median has been dropping since the middle of last year as more small investors entered the market ‚Äì large investors did, too, but they were fewer in number while greater in size. /4 https://t.co/ioTl5QW9pk

Given the regular presence of both large and small transactions but the higher weighting of small ones, the mean (which reflects the size of transfers) is always greater than the median (which reflects their distribution). (chart @glassnode) /3 https://t.co/kjpDfJ3FaQ

This was not the case in 2018 ‚Äì back then, small investors led the run-up, and the exit. We can see this in a chart of average transfer volumes. Mean transfer volume refers to the average transfer volume on any given day; median transfer volume refers to the mid-point. /2 https://t.co/d3If5dEH8f

One significant way in which this bear market is different from 2018 is the behavior of large vs small investors. While overall on-chain volumes haveüìâ, the exit has largely been from large participants, while the activity of small participants has been relatively constant. üßµ https://t.co/9ozMquDwJs

You‚Äôre probably wondering why I‚Äôm going on about Ghana and not mentioning crypto ‚Äì fair question, and the answer is that the power balance in the macro landscape is radically changing, only we don‚Äôt see it on a day-to-day basis because our attention is focused on‚Ä¶ /7

An incentive for mines to ramp up production is the increase in government buying ‚Äì on Friday, the government announced that they would buy all of the gold from small refiners in the country and 20% from large, effective Jan 1. /6 
https://t.co/hFjTsY0Evd

Many also continued to produce but did not disclose production, selling directly to foreign buyers. This is being addressed, apparently (although it‚Äôs a difficult issue to solve), and new mines are coming on stream. /5
https://t.co/E5llHwnEr1

Another potential wrinkle is the‚¨áÔ∏èin gold production in the country. Ghana used to be Africa‚Äôs largest gold producer, even ahead of S. Africa, but recent fiscal disincentives and other bureaucratic moves ended up closing many of the smaller extractors. /4
https://t.co/W3cOOqqTxo

We also now have a timeline ‚Äì the deadline for 100% of oil purchases to be paid for with gold is next October. The wrinkle? The IMF. Ghana is negotiating a $3bn program with the IMF, which may be pressured by the US to make sure this is a non-starter. ü§î/3
https://t.co/81nMKQVkTs

@tradingview A complication now is the international reaction, just as US-China relations appeared to be thawing. Were China to use force, what would the US do? What‚Äôs more, this comes at a time when Europe and other areas increasingly depend on China for trade. What would Europe do? /7

@tradingview is their timing: right after the confirmation of Xi Jinping as Chinese premier for life. In theory, this could give the authorities more leeway in suppressing the protests using whatever means necessary. /6

@tradingview Overlay this on to the unusual amount of public unrest in Iran in recent weeks, and the ‚Äúunrelated‚Äù riots in Belgium/Netherlands last night, and you have stark examples of the changing social order that some observers have been warning was coming. /4

So, innovation under regulation will be more muted ‚Äì but this is a tradeoff that, in my opinion, the market should be able to make. Innovate away outside the regulatory framework ‚Äì but, for mainstream adoption and protection, come and sit at the table. /10

And even theoretically independent organizations such as the BoE are subject to the political mood. Were they to go gung-ho on DAOs, for instance, the officials responsible could find themselves out of a job, no matter how strong the independence. /9

This sounds good ‚Äì but, generally, financial regulators‚Äô success with innovative financial regulation has not been great. Part of the issue is the rotation of those in office with responsibility for enacting long-term changes: they become short-term, and political. /8

This may sound counter-intuitive, but Cunliffe earlier makes the point that people don‚Äôt fly in unregulated airplanes. And he thinks that new business models can emerge from ‚Äúinnovation rather than regulatory arbitrage‚Äù. /7

Cunliffe then goes on to talk about potential applications of smart contracts in traditional markets to improve settlement processes ‚Äì and how it could be *easier* to foster innovation by bringing crypto into a regulatory framework. /6
This paragraph is worth replicating in its entirety ‚ú®: /5 https://t.co/4V28WSZRiW

‚ÄúThere will probably always be some who prefer ‚Äì for a variety of reasons ‚Äì to invest and trade in an unregulated, opaque world. But we should not push the majority who do not want those risks into that world because there is no regulated alternative.‚Äù /4

‚ÄúWhether or not one thinks it is sensible to invest or trade in the highly speculative assets that make up most of the activity in the crypto world, investors should be able to do so in transparent, fair and robust marketplaces.‚Äù /3

Cunliffe recognizes that the FTX failure is encouraging more activity on decentralized platforms, but is not yet convinced that they can handle the risks inherent in finance ‚Äì they have not yet been tested at scale and over time, also governance vulnerabilities. /2

BoE deputy gov Cunliffe‚Äôs speech yesterday on crypto regulation has some refreshingly supportive wording regarding crypto potential, in spite of FTX fallout. But he talks about ‚Äúregulated‚Äù innovation which involves significant tradeoffs. Some details: /1

It‚Äôs also an emotional blow to holders and builders desperate for some market sunshine after a bleak winter. To demoralize anyone, snatch hope away when it feels within reach. The shock and gloom are understandable. But it will be short-term. We will get through this.

The potential fallout could end up being even tougher for some market participants than was the Terra/3AC collapse as liquidity is thin and we don‚Äôt know who held FTT as collateral (-80% 7d, little hope of recovery) and who will be hit by the moves in SOL (-30% 24h) and others /7

Plus, the timing. Things were just starting to look up, with a bottom surely either behind us or very close, and it seemed that the fallout from May/June had worked through the system. This is a big setback to investors who thought the ‚Äúcoast‚Äù might be clear. /6

And there‚Äôs the reputational embarrassment for the industry as a whole. Sam presented constructive ideas on regulation + improvements to trad market infrastructure. The possibility that something was not ‚Äúright‚Äù with client funds could unjustly hit credibility across the board./5

Some are now going to claim they never trusted him, but Sam was generally respected and liked. We don‚Äôt yet know what happened, and it took guts to accept the problem and scramble to find a solution. But many more are going to feel personally let down than with Terra/3AC. /4

Even Mt. Gox was not as big a deal ‚Äì the industry back then was tiny and limited to bitcoiners, those involved were generally aware of the risks, and while it hurt, the contagion was largely quantifiable and contained. /3

hedge fund risk on the other. (3AC was a surprise to most, but that‚Äôs hedge funds for ya.) The FTX wipeout hits at a core piece of our market infrastructure, a piece that had a good reputation and provided a useful service to traders, investors, creators. /2

Crypto generally has its share of dramatic flare-ups, but this week‚Äôs moves have shaken the market more than anything I‚Äôve seen in years. Why? This time it *is* different. The implosions of May and June were not such a shock ‚Äì dubious incentives on the one hand, /1

The clamour for a slowdown in rate hikes ‚Äì from politicians, equity investors, home buyers‚Ä¶ ‚Äì overlooks the mess markets would be in if Powell slowed and then had to accelerate again. Short-term relief vs even worse medium-term pain is not a good recipe.

But valuations + allocation decisions are being distorted by the uncertainty. Powell‚Äôs comments *might* hint at how much longer this uncertainty will last. Unlikely just yet, but that‚Äôs what everyone will be listening for ‚Äì clues as to the pace and peak. https://t.co/ghVcFjdlss

Why Chair Powell‚Äôs comments are more important than the rates announcement itself: the biggest weight on the market right now is the *volatility* of rates, the uncertainty is a greater pain point than the actual level. Unemployment data is taken from the ‚Äúhousehold survey‚Äù of ~60k households (out of ~128m). People on unpaid leave + those in marginal, off-the-books jobs are counted as employed. Small samples, different criteria, all helping to paint a picture, but not definitive. /8 https://t.co/eGJ7qDpknC

Payroll data is taken from the ‚Äúestablishment survey‚Äù which looks at ~131,000 businesses and government agencies (out of ~8m in the US). It can double-count workers, and excludes agricultural and self-employeds without incorporated businesses. /7 https://t.co/Tb157JrsUD

Another factor is the variability of the data. The unemployment rate doesn‚Äôt swing wildly, and usually comes in close to expectations. The payroll data, however, usually misses and is often significantly revised because ‚Äúit‚Äôs complicated‚Äù. /6

So, strong figures aside, there is enough nuance to hint that the economy is not doing great. Throw in a lot of the other economic data we‚Äôre seeing, and you can‚Äôt conclude from today‚Äôs release that the Fed is going to think it has to work even harder to kill the economy. /5 https://t.co/h7WoGoecim

This situation hints at how rules don‚Äôt keep up with technology. Advances in server configuration, more sophisticated erasure techniques and transparent verification have made the recycling of storage hardware both essential and possible.

Regulation is partly responsible ‚Äì the penalties for improper data handling are steep. That is a valid concern, but a short-term one. Longer-term concerns around essential resources and energy waste get relegated to second-tier. /4

Here we have the need to ensure data privacy at odds with the sustainability goal of reuse wherever possible. It highlights the need to re-think how data storage and erasure can be verified such that fears of leaks no longer predominate. /3

The shreds are often recycled, but ~30% of the materials get lost in the process, including a meaningful amount of ‚Äúcritical‚Äù materials such as rare earths, which have worrying global supply constraints. /2

Data centres usually upgrade their servers every 3-5 years. What happens to the old ones? Usually, they are shredded to avoid possible data leaks. What if they could be reliably and safely wiped clean and resold? /1

more of a role in the correlation‚Äôs rise and fall, it will never be predominant ‚Äì prices are set by the last trade, at least one side of which is likely to have a short-term, perhaps trading-oriented view. So, high macro correlation is a feature, but not a characteristic.

As shorter-term more speculative macro investors exit and stay out, they cede more pricing power to longer-term participants with possibly different investment theses. Yet this is against low volumes, and while accumulation behaviour may play‚Ä¶ /10

The summer climb in BTC-S&P corr was not necessarily due to macro investors treating crypto as a risk asset ‚Äì many had already divested, + while speculative trading will always be a feature of crypto markets, the strong flows of funds either in or out have been largely absent. /9

The point is to not take correlation data too seriously ‚Äì it tends to move sometimes based on trend-perpetuated coincidence, or on macro sentiment, or on a totally different market attribute. ‚ÄúBitcoin is correlated‚Äù ‚Äì yes, but that doesn‚Äôt mean much. /8

What is going on? While BTC *is* a macro asset, it‚Äôs not all that it is, and the BTC-S&P correlation has cooled recently. So, the divergent trends suggest that maybe BTC is behaving more like a store-of-value asset now. Maybe ‚Äì but not necessarily. /7 https://t.co/364c2OG0Vf

Maybe the correlation jump was not due to macro overlays ‚Äì maybe it was a coincidence that falls into bucket 2, that all correlations jumped in that time. Only, they didn‚Äôt. The BTC-gold correlation, as @KaikoData points out, remained low but has now jumped. /6 https://t.co/y6Lf4YtZ7M

Then May‚Äôs Terra implosion hit crypto even more than rates fears were hitting stocks at the time. Correlation reflects directionality as well as degree, and the S&P was bouncing around. The 60d BTC-S&P 500 correlation dropped to a local low of 0.33 as macro investors exited. /5 https://t.co/7xl09ksSMs

But institutional flows started to pick up in Q4 last year, especially in the run-up to the ETF launch. Correlation, however, didn‚Äôt zoom until ~April, as stock indices were suffering and general rates uncertainty was freaking the market out. /4 https://t.co/cdsOzHnRrm

And then, late last year, they did. It was assumed (including by me) that institutional involvement was responsible for the spike in correlation. It makes sense: macro investors treating BTC as a macro risk asset will cause it to behave as such, right? /3 https://t.co/6oWGOwM1HE

But we also know that 1) correlation does not imply causation, and 2) in times of fear, all correlations go to zero. So, let‚Äôs look closer at that correlation move. For years, observers of the crypto markets were proclaiming ‚Äúthe institutions are coming!‚Äù. /2 https://t.co/806xHRKtjs

Here we go, a possibly triggering thread on BTC correlations ‚Äì happy to entertain the notion I might be wrong on some of this, so do chime in. We all know that ‚ÄúBTC is a macro asset‚Äù ‚Äì its 60d correlation w/ the S&P500 shot up earlier this year to over 7. /1 https://t.co/KXx9odu2C4

A bridge would be good, perhaps providing a discreet back door to diplomacy. Then again, this move could be as simple as Turkey switching sides. Its role in NATO is becoming increasingly contentious as it moves economically closer to Russia and China. /10 
https://t.co/BSbWYLNpKU

Turkey becoming a member of SCO while also being a member of NATO could further cement its role as a bridge between the two hemispheres, enhancing its significance on the global stage while perhaps distracting from economic misery at home. /9

Greater economic cooperation between SCO states, such as non-USD trade, could continue to strengthen ties while freeing member economies from the fierce pressure of local currencies continuing to weaken vs the USD. /8

This matters for the role of the US dollar on the global stage. India is setting up processes to facilitate the settlement of trade with Bangladesh and Russia in currencies other than the dollar ‚Äì not enough to dethrone the USD, but it sends a message. /7
https://t.co/UWK7dhK8hB

Semantics aside, it is generally seen as an eastern counterweight to NATO, and growth in its power with the ascension of Iran and possibly others is triggering some concern, especially given the increasingly stark relevance of shifting geopolitics. /6

The main purpose of the SCO is to promote regional security. This includes military cooperation, anti-terrorism coordination, intelligence sharing, and working together for regional development. Leaders of SCO states have repeatedly stated that it is NOT a military alliance. /5

Other involved countries include Afghanistan, Belarus + Mongolia who have observer status, and Sri Lanka, Cambodia, Azerbaijan, Turkey, Nepal, Armenia, Egypt, Qatar + Saudi Arabia who are dialogue partners. The US applied for observer status early on but was rejected. /4

For those not familiar, the SCO is an alliance between member states China, Russia, India, Pakistan, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan and as of next year, Iran - covering >40% of the world‚Äôs population. For comparison, NATO covers ~12%. /3
https://t.co/4karuhNXEV

We‚Äôve also seen signs of this in Erdogan‚Äôs self-appointed role as mediator in the war between Russia and Ukraine. While it shouldn‚Äôt surprise us, it is causing concern given the confrontational vibe between NATO/SCO blocs and the heightened stakes in the ‚Äúus vs them‚Äù narrative./2

Turkey‚Äôs moves to join both NATO and the eastern "equivalent" Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) should not surprise us, given the country‚Äôs traditional political, commercial and geographical role straddling east and west. /1 üßµ

Bottom line, broad yet strict regulation designed to ‚Äúprotect‚Äù can end up doing the opposite, while unnecessarily slowing innovation. More thought is needed as to what investors need protection from, and if a blunt SEC guideline is the best way to achieve that. /8

bank-run, secure crypto services will go elsewhere with possibly less security ‚Äì and public banks could conceivably come up with off-balance sheet services that hide risk (don‚Äôt know what those would look like, but banks are generally pretty good at finding legal loopholes). /7

Also, by stressing this rule for public companies, the SEC is giving an advantage to private banks, who do not have the same reporting requirements (and therefore can inadvertently hide more risk). Other ways this could lead to more instead of less risk: Clients who want... /6

This is a blow to all the legacy banks planning to offer crypto services in response to client demand ‚Äì crypto as liabilities on balance sheets means banks have to hold equivalent cash on the asset side, a prohibitive cost for many. /4

And, should crypto be singled out? The rails and nature of the assets are different but more transparent than many of the even higher volatility assets banks currently custody for clients with less onerous rules. /3

It‚Äôs not necessarily wrong that extra precautions be taken with crypto assets ‚Äì they are bearer assets that move on different rails, and their volatility multiplied by volume could cause some liquidity strain. It‚Äôs more about who should get to decide, and why. /2

A prime example of how paralyzing the current confusion as to regulatory boundaries concerning crypto can get: the SEC said that publicly quoted banks must report custodied crypto as a liability, but did so without consulting banks or their regulator. /1

That led to more complex social hierarchies, including the emergence of family/tribe economic units and the beginning of a more sedentary existence. So, next time you're out for a walk, it's worth taking a second to appreciate what that activity means for us. https://t.co/z5ZxZ4r0j4

And then our growing brains came up with increasingly sophisticated tools, which further changed the balance of energy needs, diet and biological evolution. Cooking radically expanded our range of suitable food. Which led to the need to store food, and the division of labor. /5 https://t.co/pu56p4sfgD

All of this required bigger brains. To avoid needing a higher metabolic rate for this, our intestines had to shrink ‚Äì which the introduction of energy-dense foods such as meat and nuts allowed (digestible in the small intestine, unlike straw/leaves/etc.) /4 https://t.co/RjPpAHAoTj

Walking liberated limbs to use for carrying weapons or transporting food to our people. We developed better hand dexterity. And this is amazing: walking freed up our mouths and teeth from carrying, allowing us to develop language. /3 https://t.co/IlE6shu0Nn

So why did we start walking? It‚Äôs not to intimidate predators ‚Äì it‚Äôs because of energy conservation. Using two limbs to move is more energy efficient than using four ‚Äì some studies say it uses 75% less energy. /2
https://t.co/7KwqqCCrJv

Went down a weird rabbit hole this morning on why walking pushed us to the top of the food chain. We are the only species whose main form of moving is upright. NOT saying one asset is better than the other (I never give investment advice)... I am saying they are very different, and those that like BTC can also like ETH but for different reasons, and vice versa. They are not direct substitutes - so, no, BTC will not be hurt by the Merge.

Comparing to traditional stores of value, no-one wants to worry that the gold in their vault is going to turn into something else. Ethereum‚Äôs relative flexibility may be another reason to prefer ETH over BTC as an asset ‚Äì but it‚Äôs very unlikely to make the BTC thesis weaker. /3

and low inflation, BUT it‚Äôs unlikely that investors who look for store of value characteristics such as immutability and fixed supply will dump BTC in favour of ETH. Not criticizing ETH at all, but the Merge shows it‚Äôs not exactly immutable, which is a key SOV characteristic. /2

I‚Äôve heard some analysts say that Ethereum‚Äôs Merge will hurt Bitcoin, as investors conclude that Ethereum on PoS is much better as a store of value. This is nonsense. After the Merge, investors may prefer ETH over BTC for a range of reasons, including its energy consumption‚Ä¶ /1

Unfortunately, Ghana‚Äôs situation is not unique. War, inflation, supply chain issues have highlighted stark fractures in food/fuel security that are likely to spill over into political unrest which could lead to even more hunger. Apart from tragic, this makes recovery much harder.

An IMF deal may help quell talk of sovereign default. And renewed access to debt markets may help with fuel shortages. Inflation will be a more stubborn problem, however, as well as painful in a country heavily reliant on food imports. /9
https://t.co/PPIxm5WGtr

And all this in a country that until recently was one of the leading ‚Äúgrowth stories‚Äù in Africa. Accra had an active tech scene. Ghana is Africa‚Äôs 2nd-largest gold + cocoa producer, 8th-largest oil producer and the 2nd-largest country in Western Africa. /8
https://t.co/wXqNAa3uRH

The currency depreciation has also made it increasingly hard for Ghana to service its debt. What's more, whopping rate hikes so far this year (450bp to 19%) won‚Äôt help, and its risk premium has effectively shut it out of the Eurobond market. /7
https://t.co/pSnLVBJhmr

Furthermore, its oil production dropped almost 20% last year, reportedly due to technical problems. And the cedi is down 22% against the dollar, worst perf of an African currency so far this year. Further dollar strength is likely to aggravate this. /6
https://t.co/XEQfUFIFlJ

These fuel shortages come in spite of the country being an oil producer since 2010 (but, like Nigeria, it does not have the capacity to refine the crude oil it produces). The problem is 1) rising oil prices and 2) limited access to dollars. /5
https://t.co/gzgQiWxssN

The main grievances are the usual litany of fuel shortages, inflation and corruption, plus a controversial ‚Äútax‚Äù on e-money transfers. IMF involvement might help stave off further fuel and currency shortages. /4
https://t.co/YfO76ftgVZ

The bond market liked the decision, but it‚Äôs possible the unions and other constituents won‚Äôt, since a freeze on wages is likely to be extremely unpopular with >27% inflation. Protests have been escalating anyway, with violent clashes.  /3
https://t.co/4T4aOPVbgz

Why? Because Ghana had been rejecting IMF help, thinking it could go it alone (and avoid having to meet the organization's demands, such as govt salary and hiring freezes, tax hike, removing subsidies, etc.). /2
https://t.co/wyJMa1aiLR

To make this more confusing, the UK/EU use the ‚Äú2 consecutive quarters‚Äù definition. And the World Bank/IMF define a ‚Äúglobal recession‚Äù as ‚Äúa contraction in global real GDP per capita accompanied by a broad decline in various other measures of global activity‚Äù. Some leeway there. https://t.co/h0yhDSBzWv

So, let‚Äôs be careful about throwing around the term ‚Äútechnical recession‚Äù. It isn‚Äôt true. We should say we **could** be in a technical recession. Call me pedantic, but the use of the word ‚Äútechnical‚Äù calls for a certain amount of pedantry. /7 https://t.co/iXmXuRZQIl

Another reason the NBER avoids the quarterly trap is that it needs to declare a monthly beginning and end, for more granular economic analysis. Btw there‚Äôs also no formal definition of a depression, either, other than a ‚Äúreally bad recession‚Äù. /6 https://t.co/EfdyqyjNYZ

For instance, March-April 2020 was officially a recession, even though it was only 2 months. Note that it took the NBER over a year to declare it as such ‚Äì so don‚Äôt expect any swift announcements from them should we get more really bad data in US. /5
https://t.co/ipW09RcHnn

The NBER‚Äôs definition is the following: ‚Äúa significant decline in economic activity spread across the economy, **lasting more than a few months**‚Äù. (my emphasis) Nothing about 2 consecutive quarters. Why? Because the NBER says that a recession can be shorter. /4 https://t.co/Y3ruAHOMuT

‚Ä¶which would make it difficult to combine and compare analyses and further the academic work around business cycles. So, the NBER gets to decide when we are in a recession, and this is especially important given there is no established definition of what a recession even is. /3 https://t.co/i01B9Tk0Zy

The National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER) Business Cycle Dating Committee was set up to be the quasi-official arbiter of recession dates, and is responsible for identifying peaks/troughs. This is to avoid dozens of different dates being declared, /2
https://t.co/zoMHZ49rcl

So many people are insisting that if we do see negative US Q2 GDP growth ‚Äì which several economists and even the Atlanta Fed GDPNow function are predicting ‚Äì then we are technically in a recession (2 consecutive quarters). üö®**This is not true.**üö® /1 üßµ

This chart (from @glassnode's workbench) shows that, relative to BTC market cap, BTC perpetual futures OI is at an all-time high. That‚Äôs a lot of leverage in the market, relative to size. This implies that there could be some nasty liquidations ahead. https://t.co/bddc2GtBqE

Perp futures OI on its own is not interesting. If it‚Äôs going up but market cap is going up even more, then in relative terms leverage is declining. So, I divide the BTC perp futures OI by the BTC market cap to get relative movements. Here it is:  /4 https://t.co/QrNz5RqcCH

These trade mainly on offshore crypto derivatives exchanges and usually offer notably higher leverage than contract futures. So, I use perps when I want to gauge market leverage. It‚Äôs not *all* the leverage in the market, but it‚Äôs an indicator.  /3 https://t.co/pBGnF2WI1V

First, why this metric? BTC perpetual futures are contracts that just keep rolling over ‚Äì no expiry date (hence ‚Äúperpetual‚Äù). This makes them easier for many traders/investors ‚Äì less hassle, less expiry loss, wide variety of underlying assets‚Ä¶ /2 https://t.co/VOyNgeZEQR

I‚Äôve been asked a few times over the past couple of days how much leverage there is in the crypto markets. While there is no comprehensive data on all types of leverage, I keep an eye on BTC perp open interest (OI) as a barometer, and:   /1 https://t.co/BKKZmfSu8V

‚Ä¶confuse market newcomers and support those that see bitcoin as a threat. This could offset some of the growing awareness of Bitcoin‚Äôs global role as a seizure-resistant, independent emerging store of value, given recent events on the geopolitical stage. /14

It is relatively easy these days to spin up a new blockchain, but the coolest technology ever seen is not worth much without a network of users. While the proposal is easy to dismiss as lacking in any fundamental base, the attention it is getting is likely to‚Ä¶ /13

What‚Äôs more, **it assumes that Bitcoin is just the technology**. The way Bitcoin works is a large part of the trust that users have in its value. And that trust ‚Äì even more than the technology itself (although that is the necessary base) ‚Äì is what *gives* Bitcoin its value. /12

‚Ä¶‚Äútell big tech and finance corporations to stop Bitcoin from polluting the planet‚Äù, glossing over the pollution caused by big tech and finance and overlooking the hard fact that big tech and finance corporations don‚Äôt control Bitcoin. /11

As anyone trying to change Bitcoin in the past has seen, getting that level of consensus is unattainable, even if the change were a good idea. The proposal is also flawed on a conceptual level. The campaign‚Äôs website features a petition to‚Ä¶ /10 
https://t.co/M6esjDs1xi

‚Ä¶ conceptual agreement from the start as to the general direction. It also depends on the cooperation of the entire ecosystem: all of the apps, service providers, developers + the active participation of a large portion of token holders (to secure the network as validators). /9

A change of consensus mechanism is even less likely to get any traction, as it could not be done through a fork. Ethereum plans to execute its switch from PoW to PoS with the latter chain ‚Äúabsorbing‚Äù the former. This requires years of intense development with a broad‚Ä¶ /8

What‚Äôs more, changing a consensus mechanism while a network is in action is one of the most complicated experiments of all ‚Äì just ask the Ethereum crowd. Previous efforts to change Bitcoin‚Äôs code have led to forks, with the original still easily in the lead. /7

And the ‚Äúhow‚Äù is perplexing. The @guardian goes as far as to call this a ‚Äúsimple change‚Äù in its header. It is not, and the proposal demonstrates a lack of understanding of how Bitcoin works. Bitcoin mining is complex, as is proof-of-stake technology. /6
https://t.co/b6INlvYe40

‚Ä¶but the ecosystem has not yet seen a PoS network at scale and over time, so the assumption that they are equally secure is for now based on theory, a risky premise on which to base a change to a $900 billion asset. /5
https://t.co/7Pg2lyKnh9

The ‚Äùwhy‚Äù is further complicated by the distinct security guarantees of PoW and PoS networks. This is a subject of hot debate, with Bitcoiners insisting PoW is more secure and Etherians convinced that is wrong. There are strong arguments on each side, /4

So, a smart move imo ‚Äì apply some political pressure to the US, remind it of why it needs SA ‚Äì but not a game-changer. I think the USD reserve currency role will be eroded ‚Äì different conversation ‚Äì but that will take time, and this is not the trigger.

- most oil (+ other commodity) importers will continue to prefer USD contracts
- SA would have limited use for yuan vs USD ‚Äì could pay contractors perhaps, but would need to turn the bulk into USD or euros
- the riyal is pegged to the $ ‚Äì SA needs that $ relationship /6

That‚Äôs why this was not an unexpected move. Now here‚Äôs why it won‚Äôt make much of a dent on intl markets:
- pricing oil contracts in yuan is not the same as pricing oil in yuan ‚Äì SA can accept payment in bushels of wheat if it wants, but oil will still be priced in USD /5

-  SA also apparently feels that it has not received the military support it expected regarding intervention in Yemen‚Äôs civil war and in response to a 2019 drone attack on oil processing facilities
- and Biden‚Äôs promise to turn SA into a ‚Äúpariah state‚Äù probably rankles /4

- US-Saudi relations are strained ‚Äì Crown Prince MBS is reportedly not even taking Biden‚Äôs calls (the WH denies this)
- SA has rejected US requests to increase oil production to stem the price rise, and abstained from the UN resolution condemning the Russian invasion /3

- Saudi Arabia has been talking about this for years 
- China is SA‚Äôs largest trading partner, buying 25% of oil exports
- MBS wants better relations with China, has invited Xi Jinping to visit after Ramadan ‚Äì would be Xi‚Äôs first foreign visit since the pandemic /2

The WSJ report yesterday that Saudi Arabia was considering pricing oil contracts in yuan triggered a bounce in the CNY + may be behind part of BTC‚Äôs rise yesterday (weakening of USD‚Äôs reserve status leaves room for others, right?) ‚Äì BUT not so fast... /1

Just one more take and then I‚Äôm going to sleep ‚Äì Powell‚Äôs emphasis on the strength of the labor market ‚Äì if it can withstand rate hikes like he insists, that could perpetuate inflation which would mean more rate hikes, until labor market stops being strong

For now it seems that the Fed will just let maturities roll off (mature without replacing), which is the least of the bad options on the table. And the pace of rate increases will depend on the strength of the economy and inflation. An easing of either good be a good sign.

Powell did say that the Fed was willing to move faster regarding QT this time around than last. Some are taking this as a bad sign. But last time, QE started in 2008 and the Fed didn‚Äôt get around to QT until ten years later. /2

On the whole, positive news from the Fed in that QT is not a likelihood within the next few months. The active withdrawal of liquidity from the market would have been seriously bad news for asset prices. Getting rates to 1% or even a bit higher not such a big deal. /1

With no real reason for the market to be trading sideways to slightly down, it‚Äôs more likely to have been a natural breather, which is a frequent occurrence in any bull market. /8
Some traders have blamed the news that Gensler had rejected VanEck‚Äôs application for a spot ETF, although that surprised absolutely no-one. /7

A further factor often cited is the crypto wording in the Infrastructure Bill which is now law ‚Äì but this has been well-known for some time, is factored into the market, and anyway it is likely that the crypto lobby will be able to get the impractical wording changed. /6

1) the judge would need to decide that Wright IS Satoshi, 2) would also need to decide that the plaintiff‚Äôs late brother did indeed help develop Bitcoin, and 3) Wright would need to be able to access the original address (something he has repeatedly failed to do). /5

Another is the possibility that the ongoing case against Craig Wright, who claims to be Bitcoin‚Äôs founder Satoshi Nakamoto, could unleash on the market part of Satoshi‚Äôs holdings, over 1 million BTC. This is extremely remote, as three things would have to happen: /4

It could be delayed until 2022 or even 2023, and it is a known risk, most likely priced in. Since the timing could be a way off yet, it is probably over-priced in. And many of the claims holders are hedge funds, and it is not clear they would want to sell. /3

One is the concern that the finalization last week of the Mt. Gox claims will lead to the disbursement of BTC held by the trustee, which could enter the market and depress prices. However, the timing of the disbursement is not yet clear. /2

... a transitory one. The jump in correlation is more an acknowledgement by investors that this inflation is not transitory. That, *combined* with the new technology aspects of Bitcoin, are most likely behind the spurt in bullish sentiment pushing the asset toward new highs.

Is BTC ‚Äúdigital gold‚Äù? For many traditional investors and certainly for younger investors, yes. But it‚Äôs more than that: it‚Äôs also a new technology, as the upcoming Taproot upgrade reminds us. Like gold, it will respond more to a ‚Äúpersistent‚Äù inflation narrative than ... /8

Now, is BTC an inflation hedge? Is gold? For most of this year we‚Äôve been told that the inflation we‚Äôre seeing is transitory. No reason for gold to react to that. But now that inflation seems less transitory, gold is waking up. /7 https://t.co/MHOsAL4fY9

Apart from the currency turmoil, that could exacerbate inflation concerns even further by disrupting commodity supply chains. So, we have an inflationary environment which favors hard assets, while kicking rate increases (which favor finl assets) down the road. /6

Here‚Äôs the thing: we are in an inflationary environment ‚Äì the consensus expectations for the Oct CPI is 5.8%, which would be the highest since 1990. BUT it will be hard for developed economies to raise rates without really hurting developing economies. /5  https://t.co/Ydt2O2avHZ

For instance, if inflation is rising, we can surely expect rates to rise, yes? Higher interest rates are in narrative terms not good for non-yielding assets, for the opportunity cost. So, will any inflation benefit to BTC and gold be offset by expectations of higher rates?  /4

Why will BTC futures-based ETFs not be the blowout success some expect? When we last got really excited about a possible ETF, it was not easy for retail investors to buy BTC. Now they can through Robinhood, Paypal, CashApp, etc. ‚Äì or buy COIN, MSTR or any of the listed miners. /3

First, why do I think it will happen? There‚Äôs really no reason not to. Virtually all objections have been overcome when it comes to ETFs based on CME-traded BTC futures, and Gensler has said he is not opposed, especially if under 40s Act. /2

‚Ä¶however, what this will mean for algorithmic stablecoins and for the use of stablecoins in DeFi. The regulation is mainly about protecting the financial system from risks of a run ‚Äì DAI and others may be deemed not a threat due to no reserves or the market size. For now.

‚Ä¶while limiting systemic risk. It could also boost innovation in money, allowing the private sector to issue stablecoins with coded functionalities AND the support of vetted reserves and perhaps even insurance. The potential ramifications of this are vast. It is not clear, /4

‚Ä¶it would boost confidence in the advantages of these monetary tools and perhaps encourage their use beyond crypto payments by both investors and banks. It could also encourage more banks to issue their own tokens, which could boost monetary liquidity and economic growth, /3

‚Ä¶more expensive in terms of compliance and presumably introduce requirements regarding the quality of the reserves backing the crypto assets. This could make the stablecoin business less profitable by lowering income while raising costs. BUT‚Ä¶ /2

Of course I‚Äôm not suggesting that bitcoin substitute gold on sovereign balance sheets ‚Äì that won‚Äôt happen, not for a while anyway. But surely the advantages make diversification worth thinking about.

No need to worry about being physically near a market, so no need to store your reserves in foreign (and possibly adversarial?) jurisdictions. Buying and storing, as well as moving from storage to the market, has a negligible cost in comparison. /13

5) The contrast between the handling of gold reserves and bitcoin as a reserve asset are obvious. Transparency, in real time. Worth spending on good storage, but even so, would be much cheaper than highly secure facilities surrounded by infrareds and minefields. /12

Mooney tried to introduce this bill before, without success ‚Äì he also introduced a bill in 2019 to bring back the gold standard. He doesn‚Äôt seem to have a lot of friends in the House, so we‚Äôre unlikely to see an audit any time soon. /10
https://t.co/C7sJozKQbs

4) Back to the USBD ‚Äì how much gold is there? It is declared, but is that audited? In May, Alexander Mooney (R-WV) introduced the Gold Reserve Transparency Act of 2021 to provide for the first true audit of gold reserves in more than 65 years. /10
https://t.co/6OI1NfbzGN

This makes sense ‚Äì should they want to sell gold on the international market with physical transfer, London is the place to be. But it does add a layer of vulnerability‚Ä¶ /9
https://t.co/2Syceteg8x

This happens in the UK as well. Most of Australia‚Äôs gold is held in London, for example. And here's something interesting: In 2016, China bought the precious metals storage business of Barclays Bank in the UK.
https://t.co/wMqVXrqg8G

The NY Fed offers gold custody as a service to central banks, govts and intl orgs. Yes, many countries hold gold, a sovereign bearer asset, on their balance sheets but store it in the US, which‚Ä¶ sort of defeats one of the asset‚Äôs main advantages. /6 https://t.co/JuQ3h2il5i

That honor goes to the vault of the Federal Reserve of New York, in Manhattan, which holds 5,620 metric tons vs the USBD‚Äôs 4,580 metric tons. But here‚Äôs the thing: most of the gold held there does not belong to the US. /5

3) The USBD holds just over half of the US gold. Most of the rest is distributed between vaults in West Point, NY and Denver, CO. Many think the USBD is the largest gold vault in the world. It isn‚Äôt. /4 https://t.co/S3M1WhxKqQ

2) When most people say ‚ÄúFort Knox‚Äù, they mean the United States Bullion Depository which is next to the army installation called Fort Knox. While one helps protect the other, they are not the same entity. The Depository is owned and run by the Treasury dept. /3
At the time, as the world was readying for war again, that was a real possibility. Now, however, the idea that a centralized depository would be seen as more secure today seems almost quaint. /2

Found myself reading up on Fort Knox this morning, don‚Äôt remember why. Here are some fascinating details I didn‚Äôt know:
1) It was built by the Treasury in 1936 to house gold stored in NY and Philly, which were seen as vulnerable to a foreign attack. /1 (image from Wikipedia) https://t.co/iClZiXv8zh

Or 3) tax private stablecoins out of existence and replace them with a CBDC. If I had to bet, I think it will be 1) ‚Äì would increase costs, but would give regulatory clarity and ‚Äúpermission‚Äù for others to innovate ‚Äì and, the least disruptive for the financial system. /6

Proposals include 1) turning issuers into banks w/ FDIC coverage (poss for USDC since its contract is more like deposits, not poss for USDT), 2) require stablecoins to be 100% backed by T-bills/CB reserves (could distort markets by significantly increasing demand for these) ‚Ä¶ /5

An interesting (and poss. relevant) detail is that tether != others in that its terms do not obligate it to redeem 1 USDT for $1 (debt contract) ‚Äì instead it will sell some underlying assets and share proceeds (equity contract) ‚Äì diff regulation, more like money market funds /4

‚Äì and given stablecoins‚Äô growth, a run on one of the majors could disrupt markets if the issuer has to fire sale the backing assets ‚Äì this is a reasonable concern, given what happened with money market funds in 2008 and 2020 (Fitch, ECB have also made this point) /3

The authors argue against letting stablecoins develop unchecked, insisting that will lead to systemic financial instability ‚Äì they bring up the overlooked concept of NQA, or no questions asked, a requisite characteristic of money (1 USDT, for example, is not always $1) ... /2

If crypto gets regulated at the federal level, it would boost confidence, inflow of funds + structure investment, and would signal the full embrace of crypto from the existing establishment. And then it‚Äôs ‚Äúgame on‚Äù. /end

And some risks. Too much regulation could stifle DeFi innovation, push a lot of crypto use off the regulated venues + trigger sector concentration. But Gensler, who has proposed this, understands the workings and the potential. /5

A lot of complications ahead, though ‚Äì first, definitions. Will crypto be squeezed into an existing taxonomy, or will it create a new one? What about settlement finality? Are stablecoins ‚Äúmoney‚Äù? Some exciting talks ahead. /4 https://t.co/YCRlpmyR92

As far as I understand (correct me if I‚Äôm wrong), crypto exchanges in the US are not ‚Äúregulated‚Äù, they are ‚Äúlicensed‚Äù, not the same thing. They‚Äôre not regulated ‚Äòcos crypto has not yet had a designated regulator (unlike securities and derivatives). /3

Making US crypto exchanges get licensed state-by-state was always gonna be just a stop-gap and an expensive one at that ‚Äì FinCEN does not consider cryptocurrencies ‚Äúlegal tender‚Äù, but considers their exchanges money transmitters? /2

Wow, this could be very good news ‚Äì the current crypto regulatory scene in the US is fragmented, inefficient, insecure and a drag on industry growth. There are risks, but even just the process of thinking about this will have some beneficial effects. /1üßµ

To be clear, bitcoin is not the only sanctions-busting tool in use ‚Äì Turkey and Dubai are conduits for a significant amount of trade with Iran. Lawyers armed with ‚Äúblocking statutes‚Äù (which in theory protect domestic companies from retaliation ... /10

3 ‚Äì Do financial sanctions even work? Iran reportedly now has more enriched uranium than before the US withdrew from the nuclear agreement. If they don‚Äôt work, for how much longer will banks be willing to bear the considerable additional cost? /9
2 ‚Äì To what extent does economic sanctions avoid the need to send in the military? Will sanction avoidance increase the incidence of armed conflict? (Let's hope not.) /8
1 - Should European countries (for example) have to comply with US political decisions? The US has threatened any business dealing with Iran with retaliation and financial excommunication. /7

Iran using bitcoin to pay for imports ‚Äì maybe medical aid, maybe food, maybe hardware for a weapons program ‚Äì returns some financial autonomy to the region. It also opens up a fascinating list of deep questions. /6

Some have suggested that the possibility that sanctioned nations would resort to bitcoin would lead the US to ban the cryptocurrency. But attempts to do so in Nigeria and more recently Turkey have led to enough protest to mitigate the message. /5

Coinbase is less like an exchange and more like a neo-bank likely to appeal to a younger generation of investors.
Let‚Äôs remember that when Amazon listed, many expressed shock that it could command a higher multiple than traditional retail giants.

-Coinbase offers interest on savings accounts.
-It is not limited to one type of value transfer system, unlike exchanges.
-Coinbase offers easy onboarding to out-there financial innovation (staking, DeFi swaps‚Ä¶)
/4

-Coinbase offers not just more, but also very *different* services. Traditional exchanges make money mainly on trading and data fees. Coinbase has trading, custody, prime brokerage, debit card, merchant services, stablecoins‚Ä¶   /3

-It‚Äôs not regulated like an exchange. 
-It has more competition.
-It offers a much broader range of services (= more diversified growth potential) 
/2

Coinbase is listing today, and its valuation will be compared to traditional exchanges (as in, how could it be higher than ICE or CME???). This is not a relevant comparison. We think of #Coinbase as an exchange because it has an order book, but there the similarities end. üßµ/1

The turning point last week was that now everyone who isn‚Äôt living in a cave is aware that the rules are skewed, and most will have an opinion, even if not totally informed. Public sentiment on this issue has been triggered. 9/n

We can‚Äôt say the ‚Äúmarket is broken‚Äù ‚Äì it worked the way it was meant to work. Yes, the rules are skewed, and end up making even worse the already excruciatingly problematic inequality in our society. But this is not new. 8/n

@afuturemodern @CoinDesk they tend to move together, but represent different things (market-wide implied profit, vs actual aggregate net profit on transactions) - I tend to look at MVRV for longer-term shifts, but prefer SOPR for short-term

@afuturemodern @CoinDesk yup, MVRV hit a 3yr high in early Jan (now -30% from there) - MVRV refers to market value/aggregate amount spent across all holdings, it's a market-wide indicator - SOPR is by transaction, speaks to the profit made on buys/sells
Some good arguments here https://t.co/3WnPAyDvwf

@AtlasPulse agree, selling of course could continue after SOPR hits 1, not all investors are in loss - and in a panic, some investors will cut their losses and run - but it's a fun sentiment indicator, shows off some of the unique metrics of crypto assets
More on SOPR and MVRV (and other metrics) on @CoinDesk's Research Hub https://t.co/nbrn8u1oHI

Spent Output Profit Ratio: the value of transactions at the market price / transactions valued at their acquisition prices. SOPR<1 = investors selling at a loss. They generally don't like to do that, so SOPR<1 implies an approaching floor as the sell supply is withheld.

@C1aranMurray true - and it could retaliate if network participants do what it doesn't want them to - but if , because of this, stablecoin networks become widely used even in emerging economies, in *theory* the US will have less control over who has access
8 ‚Äì this last point could be bad news for the global financial pyramid ‚Äì if more economies depend on the dollar, that increases US power and makes the global economy more vulnerable

7 ‚Äì good for the dollar ‚Äì with the U.S. leading the charge on this, it is likely that dollar-backed stablecoins will become the de facto global settlement token, further consolidating  the dollar‚Äôs hegemony

6 ‚Äì good for the global economy ‚Äì more efficient cross-border settlements will be good for trade, lowering the costs of documentation and compliance and maybe finally giving blockchain supply chain + trade finance apps the piece they‚Äôve been missing
5 ‚Äì good for liquidity ‚Äì more crypto dollars sloshing around a system that allows for interchangeable programmable settlement tokens is likely to allow for better optimization of use of capital
4 ‚Äì good for financial innovation ‚Äì banks can use stablecoins, but they can also ISSUE them, potentially with bells and whistles and functionalities attached

3 ‚Äì good for the banking sector, potentially opening the door to new types of financial products as well as payment and collateral services (and this is where we are likely to see ‚Äúmainstream‚Äù financial adoption)
2 ‚Äì good for traditional markets, as it is likely to encourage the emergence of a new type of lower cost and more transparent settlement system
1 ‚Äì good news for crypto markets: this is a nudge to traditional banks to offer support for blockchain infrastructure and even facilitate crypto transactions

@nsquaredcrypto agree, it was cringe-y - someone less charitable than myself called the ISG division the "dumb money" - other divisions in Goldman handle the "smart money" (hedge funds, professional traders, large institutions) - they are the ones to watch

I talk about this and more in the Crypto Long & Short newsletter for @coindesk (shameless plugüòä) ‚Äì if you don‚Äôt subscribe, you should, it‚Äôs free, it‚Äôs weekly, it‚Äôs got music & rhythm and you can sign up here:
https://t.co/z8z2kWOBi4

That said, there‚Äôs no excuse for the inanity of the analysis. But it wasn‚Äôt ‚ÄúGoldman Sachs‚Äù, it was the firm‚Äôs private clients division. The securities division and trading desk almost certainly have a more nuanced and better informed view. /7

Investing clients‚Äô money in direct assets such as bitcoin or gold would 1) not be as profitable in terms of fees, and 2) put the ISG group at huge reputational risk should bitcoin not perform well. We can‚Äôt blame them for not wanting to go there. /6

The presentation, with its a disconcertingly rosy economic outlook, was to reassure clients that their blue-chip holdings were safe and no irksome threats from edgy assets will disrupt their comfortable portfolio structures. /4
It manages private and corporate money, and I imagine you don‚Äôt park your wealth at Goldman for it to undertake risky plays. You park it there to have your hand held. /3

The presentation everyone is talking about was by the Investment Strategy Group within the Consumer and Investment Management Division, which is independent from Global Investment Research and Global Markets. This is the private clients division. /2 https://t.co/2jziihX0QP

@Izquieterzzz @coindesk üòò
7) Raise rates to combat that inflation, after encouraging everyone to take out more loans, and you could have another crisis on your hands.  /end

6) In a supply shock, there‚Äôs not much that monetary policy can do, especially when rates are at historically low levels anyway. Helicopter money could help ‚Äì but give people a chunk of money to spend during a supply shock, and you could get runaway inflation.  /8
5) Try to keep the budget deficit in check while boosting relief by cutting spending elsewhere, and you could lose the next election.  /7

4) Fiscal measures could help, but they bring political consequences. Boost relief, help ailing companies, compensate for mandated losses ‚Äì budget deficits go through the roof. This affects govts‚Äô ability to borrow, which affects debt markets, which feeds back into int rates. /6

And they won‚Äôt get businesses to borrow in order to spend ‚Äòcos everyone is spooked. No-one knows when supply chains will get back to normal, or when demand will recover from the secondary effects. /5
3) Rate cuts won‚Äôt have any effect on a pandemic. The theory is they will help businesses by lowering debt costs. Maybe, but that won‚Äôt make much difference if there‚Äôs no demand.  /4

2) This crisis is a supply shock. Pandemics affect supply chains by closing factories and constricting logistics. They become a demand shock when companies have to close because there‚Äôs nothing to sell, or customers can‚Äôt get to you.  /3

1) 2008 was a banking/financial crisis. This isn‚Äôt. That‚Äôs important because when debt is the main culprit, lowering interest rates can make a difference. Especially when you actually have interest rates to lower.  /2

@FT Does anyone know of any studies on the ‚Äúilliquidity premium‚Äù? Would like to read more on this.

@FT Or, the lack of a public market price could end up being an advantage, in that private investments can enjoy some form of accounting smoothing and don‚Äôt necessarily have to be marked sharply down.  /8

@FT For many investors, greater liquidity is good. But for large endowments, pension funds, etc., not necessarily. At least for now. If markets turn south and funds get hit with redemptions and/or payments, liquidity could look attractive.  /7

@FT Back to security tokens: true, a large part of the preference for illiquid investments is due to the lack of returns anywhere else. But why would security tokens give better returns than private options?   /6

@FT Public vehicles are easier to value for balance sheets ‚Äì just take the market price. But there‚Äôs no leeway: private investments have more valuation options, which means returns can seem smoother. Lower volatility = ‚Äúlower risk‚Äù=> ‚Äúrisk-adjusted returns‚Äù look even better.  /5
@FT And there‚Äôs the illiquidity premium of 2%, acc to Northern Trust. This is being whittled down, though, as demand for illiquid investments increases.   /4

2) Even negative yields can be a good deal, relatively speaking. Given a choice between a 10-year government bond yielding -1% and a 10-year corporate bond yielding +2%, I might feel safer with the former option. At least I know I‚Äôll get my money back.   /7
‚Ä¶money market operations. Getting a positive yield is not as important as having liquidity.  /6

Because cash can‚Äôt be moved easily or quickly, it can‚Äôt be used for repo. Government bonds, even ones with negative yields, on the other hand‚Ä¶ Many banks and investors hold government debt for repo purposes. This is a significant part of their daily‚Ä¶   /5

b) You can‚Äôt easily move physical cash. And certainly not quickly. Stacks and stacks of bills require special security, and can be SLOW to move from one place to another (not to mention risky, see above). A digitally represented bond, however, moves in seconds.  /4

And the risk is higher with cash. A vault may be secure, but at some point the cash will have to be moved, and we‚Äôve all seen those movies. A government bond, even with a negative yield, is safer and probably cheaper (negative yield, fees, whatever).   /3

1) Cash is not usually a viable option. Banks are not going to sell their L-T bonds to stuff their vaults with cash. a) Cash is expensive to transport and hold, even if the vault is yours ‚Äì there‚Äôs a negative yield right there.   /2

Bullard points out that, locally, people want a uniform currency. Less risk and more convenience. But the international monetary order remains controversial, with volatile fluctuations. /9

One of the MAIN factors in currency value is the credibility of future issuance. Bullard implies that even bitcoin doesn‚Äôt meet this criteria, ‚Äòcos of possible forks. Nor do other privately-issued cryptos, due to business model risk.  /8

Take a moment to appreciate again that this is from the president of a US FEDERAL RESERVE BANK. On the same slide, he does remind us that government backing has historically been important for currency stability and reliability. /7 https://t.co/Yzge1Hc8QY

Should there be limits on the number of ‚Äúprivate‚Äù currencies that can be issued? Historically, a profusion of currencies hasn‚Äôt worked. It‚Äôs not convenient. But there does seem to be a ‚Äúdrift‚Äù towards more than 1 currency in the US. /6

Private and public currencies can co-exist. What would make a private currency successful? If it facilitates exchange that would otherwise not occur. What if those exchanges aren‚Äôt legal (eg. drugs or violating capital controls)? /5 https://t.co/QHY2HCOnEw
There‚Äôs a nod to micro-currencies such as cigarettes. And a reminder that currency competition is nothing new. /4 https://t.co/o7ZGmjTSoW

Get this, ‚Äúcurrency is an intrinsically worthless object that has value in equilibrium only because others are expected to accept it in exchange.‚Äù The value of a currency could go to 0 if people stop accepting it. Currencies are *fragile*. /3

President Bullard puts cryptocurrencies in the context of ongoing global currency competition, and posits that they are pushing the US towards a non-uniform currency system. This may add to currency volatility. /2 https://t.co/qEw0pdtFIg

And 3) the ‚Äúproportional and consistent application of regulation of decentralised financial technologies‚Äù ‚Äì proportional to the risks they pose, and consistent across jurisdictions, even those that prefer the technology-neutral approach.  /end, finally

The FSB recommends that the G20 address 1) the applicability of current financial regulation to decentralized services and products, 2) how decentralized technologies can help with oversight and enforcement‚Ä¶   /14
The overall message is that some risks will be solved for with DLTs, but new ones will emerge.    /13

Some risks for DLT in trade finance: new forms of concentration risk (entire chains relying on same tech provider), jurisdictional issues, lack of clarity on accountability for fraud or errors, difficulty of protecting against forgery.   /12

Some risks for asset tokenization: concentration of validating nodes/miners, custody issues, settlement finality, forks (who owns the asset?), and mis-matched liquidity. See also this by @izakaminska   /11  https://t.co/Oq3WSMMh1P

Some of the risks in DLT for x-border payments: settlement finality, blockchain interoperability, difficulty of stopping money laundering ‚Äì plus, the growing  use of stablecoins means increased exposure to the issuer.  /10

And decentralized finance could reduce the efficacy of central bank interventions, which are usually useful for re-establishing market stability (or, it could prompt a re-design of central bank actions).   /9

They could also give rise to greater procyclicality if lending decisions are made by an algorithm, and allow a build up of risk in areas of finance that do not have strong oversight (a new type of ‚Äúshadow banking‚Äù?).   /8

BUT they could give rise to new forms of concentration risk such as control over code, ownership of assets and operation of the infrastructure. Governance oversight is tricky, esp with DAOs and forks.  /7

Decentralised financial technologies may reduce some stability risks associated with traditional intermediaries by increasing diversity and decreasing concentration of risk on balance sheets. They could also increase resilience to cyber attacks.   /6

The adoption of decentralized technologies such as DLT can be helped by other new techs such as AI, big data, IoT, 5G and edge computing, as they can lower the barriers to entry for previously centralized services.   /5
Applications displaying all three forms of decentralisation ‚Äúseem unlikely to achieve an economically significant scale in the near term.‚Äù   /4

3 diff types of decentralization: 1) of decision making (move away from a single trusted intermediary), 2) of risk taking (credit and liquidity risk moves off institutions‚Äô balance sheets) and 3) of record keeping (moving away from central databases).  /3

Takeaways from the report prepared by the FSB for the G20 presidency on ‚Äúdecentralized financial technologies‚Äù: a sober assessment of benefits AND RISKS from a global point of view. The risks part was especially interesting. /1

(Tagging @MarcHochstein, @mikejcasey, @nikhileshde, @TeanaTaylor and @CarrascosaCris, per recent offline FATF head-scratching and head-shaking)

So, the thorough implementation of FATF guidelines ‚Äì whatever they may end up being ‚Äì could end up being delayed by years, through legal technicalities and political realities. Gotta love them speed bumps.   /end

Now, I‚Äôm not a lawyer (real lawyers pls jump in and correct me if I got things wrong!) and European structure is damn complicated and maybe there‚Äôs an automatic over-ride which will implement whatever FATF says. But I seriously doubt it will be an easy process. /17

What‚Äôs more, AMLD5 is technically a ‚Äúdirective‚Äù, not a ‚Äúlaw‚Äù ‚Äì but it does require member states to adjust their national laws accordingly. Normally this isn‚Äôt a problem, but in the increasingly fractious Europe post-election, it could be. /16

And ministers have acknowledged that it won‚Äôt solve the money-laundering risk, since transfers can easily happen off-exchange and without custodial wallets. They‚Äôre working on plugging that gap (in itself worrying, but that's for later).  /15

It‚Äôs an update to AML4 (implemented June 2017), which was drawn up according to the previous set of FATF guidelines. It doesn‚Äôt go as far as the ‚Äútravel rule‚Äù, however. /14  https://t.co/onKTKyGHxU

And anyway, Europe recently passed AML5, an updated anti-money laundering guideline which imposes due diligence and KYC requirements on crypto exchanges and custodial wallets. The deadline for implementation is Jan 10, 2020. /13 https://t.co/sKA5tuVjXO

You can see the potential battle brewing here, right? ‚ÄúRights and freedoms of the individual‚Äù are a political hot potato, especially given polarising political trends across the bloc, likely to come to light in tomorrow‚Äôs elections.  /12

There is another exception to GDPR: payment service providers can handle customers‚Äô data ‚Äúfor the purposes of legitimate interests, **except where such interests are overridden by the interests, rights or freedoms of the individual**‚Äù. /11

With Euro-skeptics having a stronger say, it will be so much harder to get enough agreement to amend existing law (such as GDPR‚Äôs privacy rules) or get new ones passed. So, Europe may not be able ‚Äì BY LAW ‚Äì to follow FATF guidelines.  /10

This is important because until now Europe has been dominated by the centre-right or centre-left. This made it easier to get laws pushed through the 3 bodies (reminder: the European Commission proposes, the Parliament and Council decide and enact). ‚öñÔ∏è¬†/9

The European Parliament is the only European body directly elected by European citizens. And there are elections on Sunday!! (If you‚Äôre in Europe, vote!!). Polls point to a strong showing by anti-establishment parties. /8

(Note that the Council of the EU is not the same as the European Council. Isn‚Äôt Europe fun?) The Council is comprised of officials from the member states, most of whom have a lot going on at the moment, politically speaking. /7
And the three bodies don‚Äôt always agree. This is significant, and likely to get even more complicated over the next few years. /6

Bear in mind that the European Commission was one of the founding members of FATF, and is responsible for proposing and implementing laws. But the European Parliament and the Council of the EU decide on what becomes law. /5
But FATF guidelines ARE NOT LAW. And getting anything into law in the EU is a long and arduous process. /4

Under GDPR, payment service providers can handle customers‚Äô data, even without explicit consent, to ‚Äúensure the performance of a contract‚Äù, or to ‚Äúcomply with legal obligations‚Äù.  /3 https://t.co/hFy87301J3
GDPR has strict rules about what service providers can do with personal data - generally they can‚Äôt even collect it without users‚Äô explicit consent. Payments data is different, however. /2

More on the pending FATF guidelines, how they might be impacted by privacy rules, and some nerdy but important stuff on EU structure: in Europe, we have GDPR, a sweeping privacy law implemented a year ago today. üéÇüéà/1
