Now, I'm (obviously) not a lawyer nor a developer, and there may be factors I'm missing or just plain getting wrong. But I just don't see how it would be workable without seriously limiting cryptocurrencies' potential.
So, how can they be expected to keep an eye out for suspicious activity? And if they aren‚Äôt expected to do so, what‚Äôs the point of the KYC?
It‚Äôs also unclear how that would work. Exchanges see what movements happen on their platform. But wallet providers don‚Äôt get to monitor what people do with the wallets once downloaded.

But wallet providers?? In theory, it could be that we will no longer be able to download wallet software without also going through KYC. This sort of defeats one of the main appeals of bitcoin: access to all.

The FATF is apparently going to insist that the ‚Äútravel rule‚Äù be applied by cryptocurrency exchanges and wallet providers. KYC is already a part of crypto exchanges in regulated jurisdictions, so things won‚Äôt change much for onboarding.

This information is not shared with the government unless the financial institution suspects that something is amiss, in which case it files a Suspicious Activity Report, upon which the feds swoop in (maybe).

This rule became effective in 1996 and was issued by FinCEN, concurrently with the new Bank Secrecy Act recordkeeping rules for funds transfers, with the aim of creating an information trail to help with financial crime investigation.
This information includes the name, acct number, address and financial institution of the transmitter, same for the recipient, and the amount of the order.

First, what is the transfer rule? It‚Äôs the affectionate term for Bank Secrecy Act rule [31 CFR 103.33(g)], which says that all financial institutions must pass on certain information to the next financial institution when executing a transfer or payment.

@La__Cuen you're right... could also be argued that the tax income from casinos is a factor
As with casinos, whether we bother to look at that information, and what we do with it, should be up to us.  /end, finally

And full information equality is an unrealistic expectation. ‚ÄúInsiders‚Äù will always know more. But information on which we can base investment decisions could be made available to all, no matter what our original wealth.  /12

Traditionally, information distribution was expensive. Smaller companies didn‚Äôt have the resources to make sure that everyone had access to the statements, etc. Now, however, information is cheap and everywhere.  /11
Sure, retail investors *could* have access to all this if they put in the hours and scrounged up the money for the Bloomberg terminal or whatever. But‚Ä¶ fair?  /10

And 3) Does this limitation make markets more ‚Äúfair‚Äù? Even with public securities and ‚Äúfairly‚Äù distributed information, professional investors have access to enhanced analysis and metrics ‚Äì not exactly evenly distributed. /9

Problems with that: 1) This is not necessarily true (afaik there‚Äôs nothing to stop them from putting everything into one idea and losing it all). 2) It doesn‚Äôt guarantee that info is evenly distributed even among accredited investors.  /8

Still, limiting *access* to private investments can be seen as ‚Äúunfair‚Äù, giving additional opportunities for return to those that pass a wealth test. The assumption is that ‚Äúaccredited investors‚Äù can more easily absorb losses. /7

Lottery tickets are different in that the even distribution of information and risk is embedded in the system itself ‚Äì studying the odds and refining techniques will not improve your chances per ticket bought. /6

Now, in a casino, not everyone goes to the trouble of studying the odds and the techniques. But they could if they wanted. Some do, and thus have an advantage. Individual choice. The information is there if anyone‚Äôs interested. /5

In a casino and with lottery tickets, the risks are (in theory) well known. The odds are available for all to see, and the house and other players do not have access to privileged information. Risk and information are evenly distributed. /4

‚Ä¶and makes the markets less ‚Äúfair‚Äù. A big part of the SEC‚Äôs role is to make sure that markets are ‚Äúfair‚Äù. And it‚Äôs not hard to see that, with private equity (and ICOs), information and risk are unevenly distributed. /3
Private equity is largely off-limits to retail investors because of information asymmetry: founders and some investors will have more information than others. This gives some investors an edge‚Ä¶  /2

I never understood why retail investors were blocked from ‚Äúrisky‚Äù investments but could spend without limit on lottery tickets and casinos. But today I learned that it‚Äôs not about *degree* of risk. It‚Äôs about its distribution. /1

Hard to tell ‚Äì there is likely to be more demand from miners, but those outside the US (the majority) are probably well served in their markets anyway. Speculators may prefer this type of contract because the settlement‚Ä¶        /9
But Till‚Äôs paper shows that that is not enough. Will physically-delivered futures be more successful?    /8

So, bitcoin has no *commercial* need for cash-settled futures. Speculative need, sure. Funds want to hedge their positions against adverse market movements, and speculators want to take a contrarian view. Understandable.      /7
Cash-settled futures markets in commodities are common, but are traditionally for non-deliverables, such as oil and cattle.      /6

But they would much rather have physically-delivered hedging. In their markets, there are unregulated liquid exchanges that offer that. Having to turn their bitcoin into cash before settling is an unwanted extra step.        /5

Bitcoin satisfies 2) and 3), but not 1) ‚Äì with some caveats. Wheat farmers (for example) have a commercial need for hedging ‚Äì they need to know what their future cash flow will be. In bitcoin, we have the miners‚Ä¶       /4

A 2014 paper by Hilary Till, a research associate at the EDHEC-Risk Institute, looked at why and identified 3 clear elements that determined a futures contract‚Äôs success: /2 @EDHECRisk    https://t.co/PsT0LEXsYS

Right, time for some thoughts on why the Cboe bitcoin futures contract was not successful. First, this is not unusual. Traditionally, most commodity-based futures contracts fail, according to a 1981 paper by William Silber. /1
https://t.co/NNTCDxCWpL

7/ And, the SEC does have jurisdiction over some derivatives, such as options on securities. Messy, hunh?

5/ Just imagine if ethereum had had to deal with both CFTC and SEC oversight in its early days. Would it have gotten the ecosystem buy-in it ended up with? Or would it have been suffocated by competing compliance?

4/ And who regulates something that starts out as a security but then changes? SEC officials have pointed out that with digital assets, this is possible. What if the SEC and the CFTC don‚Äôt agree on whether a digital asset is a security or not?

3/ With digital assets, the boundaries between what the CFTC and the SEC regulate can get blurred. The CFTC regulates derivatives, the SEC regulates securities. But what if it‚Äôs not clear *what* an asset is?

2/ Crypto markets developed rapidly without clear regulatory guidance ‚Äì policy makers now have to grapple with how to bring these already extensive markets into regulatory compliance without harming innovation.
1/ The CFTC and the SEC have different statutes and policies which cover a ton of different asset types. BUT they were not crafted with such novel products as digital assets in mind.

BUT a prolonged bear market could do serious damage to private equity ‚Äì and, with limited liquidity, could prove to be more damaging to fund valuations than public securities. /6

This ‚Äúsmoothing‚Äù makes the fund returns much less volatile than pure stock market funds. When stock prices fall, private equity funds fall less sharply. This means they‚Äôre less likely to have to divest at low prices. /5

Also, determining the value of private equity is not as simple as ‚Äúchecking the price‚Äù ‚Äì so valuations are not carried out that often. This is good news to those who do not want to be reminded of how volatile their investments are. /4
Therefore, investing in private equity gives exposure to debt, beyond investment fund limits. Potentially higher returns, without actually taking on extra debt. /3

It‚Äôs partly about exposure to debt. Institutional investors may have limits on how much they can borrow (= leverage). Private businesses generally take on a lot of debt (because they don‚Äôt have access to public financing). /2

Pinning bitcoin's "utility" (I mean, "intrinsic value") on a jurisdiction making it the currency of choice is... well, befuddling.

"Intrinsic value" implies a utility beyond speculation - which bitcoin (to name one) *does* have. It is a technology that enables the transfer of information between parties without going through a middleman. That's useful, and that utility is its intrinsic value.

"The best way to view cryptocurrencies is as speculative tokens of no intrinsic value. One could have value if it became the currency of choice of a jurisdiction."... which misses the point, not just of crypto but of tech more broadly

‚Ä¶what kind of participation we should aim for and what role we want wealth ‚Äì whatever that ends up meaning ‚Äì to play in our kids‚Äô lives. There‚Äôs suffering, disillusionment and anger all around, and it‚Äôs spreading. But‚Ä¶ /10

So, when I read about the deepening unhappiness with the current system, and on @coindesk every day I see evidence of progress (baby steps) towards a more fluid and just distribution of ideas, opportunity, influence and wealth,‚Ä¶ /8

‚Ä¶join the search for a solution to capitalism‚Äôs woes, some of them not even aware that that‚Äôs what they‚Äôre doing. More and more brilliant people are applying their brain power to either the big picture or a small cog in the giant machine. /6

Who gets access? How much control should the authorities have? How can they continue to protect their citizens and keep the peace while encouraging growth and progress? /3
